faq.question: What are the system requirements?
faq.answer: A recent version (released in 2017 or later) of Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Apple Safari or Microsoft Edge is required. A laptop or desktop computer with Google Chrome or Mozilla Firefox is recommended for best experience, as certain features may be disabled in Apple Safari or Microsoft Edge.

faq.question: Is Dithermark open source?
faq.answer: Yes! Dithermark is open source and released under the MIT license. You can get the source code on the Dithermark GitHub page.

faq.question: I think I've found a bug, what should I do?
faq.answer: First, read through this FAQ and see if it addresses your problem (particularly that you meet the minimum system requirements). If nothing helps, please open an issue on our GitHub issues page. While we appreciate you taking the time to help improve Dithermark, please be aware that it is maintained by a single person for free, so it might be some time before your issue is addressed.

faq.question: Where do the random images come from?
faq.answer: The random images are provided by Unsplash, courtesy of their free photo API.

faq.question: Why does my browser crash when opening an image?
faq.answer: Opening very large images on mobile devices has been found to crash the browser. Make sure the 'Shrink large images' option is checked in the 'settings' tab. If this still does not help, try opening a smaller image, such as by selected 'Random image' from the 'open' tab, and then pixelate the image by selecting the option in the 'image' tab (this has the same effect as shrinking the image). Now try reopening the image that caused your browser to crash.

faq.question: Why does opening an image from a URL not work?
Should I enable WebGL?
faq.answer: WebGL is enabled by default as it leverages the power of your GPU to complete tasks 30-100 times faster. Dithermark uses WebGL (when enabled) for everything except the error propogation dithers and optimize palette functionality. The only times when it might be advisable to disable WebGL is if you are noticing a large amount of artifacts in the random dithers, or you are opening images that are too large to fit in a single WebGL texture unit (you will see a warning if this is the case). If you do not see an option to enable WebGL, that means your device/browser doesn't support it. In that case do not worry, as everything will still work, it will just be slower than if your device supported WebGL.

faq.question: Why are there artifacts in the random dithers?
What happened to my saved settings/palettes?
Why does saving my image fail?
faq.answer: On browsers lacking HTMLCanvasElement.toBlob() support (Apple Safari and Microsoft Edge), exporting a large image may fail. In that case, reset the zoom level to 100 and then right click on desktop/long press on mobile on the image you want to save. Select the 'Save image' or 'Save image asâ€¦' menu option to save your image as a png file.

faq.question: What file type should I use when exporting an image?
faq.answer: It is recommended you use the png file type when exporting your images, as it avoids undesirable compression artifacts. However, in certain situations (such as when exporting a large, unpixelated image), exporting as a jpeg may result in a smaller file in exchange for a negligible loss in quality.

faq.question: Where can I learn more about dithering or color quantization?
faq.answer: Our appendix page provides links to resources where you can learn more about image dithering, color quantization and other related topics.
